Equation (16) shows that in order to achieve a low concentration of first particles at the flocculator outlet, a high \bar \Lambda, it is necessary to design a flocculator with high collision strength, G_{CS}\theta.

The collision potential, G_{CS}\theta, is a property of the flocculator itself, independent of the characteristics of the raw water, the coagulant dosage, and the design of the sedimentation process. The flocculator of the AguaClara plant is designed with a minimum collision potential of |Gt.FlocBod|, which has been successful in plants that have a sludge blanket.

However, unlike some conventional methodologies, no raw water characteristics are considered in the design of the AguaClara flocculator other than the general need for the flocculation, sludge blanket, and sedimentation processes to remove suspended solids. That is, the design is independent of the results of jug tests or other preliminary analysis because the jug test cannot capture the key process in the sludge blanket. The only predictive model factors considered in the design are those related to the potential for collisions and the effect of water viscosity. Rather than knowing the characteristics of the raw water, the goal is to design a flocculator that can effectively flocculate any suspension with sufficient coagulant coverage. That is why the design tool does not ask for any user input related to treatability testing. Raw water only enters the design of coagulant and chlorine dosers where the demand for these two chemicals at the most critical times determines the maximum dosage.
The design of AguaClara has been formulated to be independent of raw water for two main reasons:

list_item.paragraph: Pitcher test results can be useful in determining coagulation efficiency by varying the coagulant dose, but they are not normally applied to full-scale flocculation because of fundamental process differences, such as the large variety of local speed gradients in shaker reactors and the lack of the sludge blanket process in the pitcher test.

The characteristics of raw water always vary over time, and in many cases it is difficult to obtain a representative set of data within the time and budget available for the study and design of the plant. One of AguaClara’s main goals is to provide effective solutions that reduce costs and time as much as possible in order to serve the maximum number of people.

section.paragraph: The design takes into account the filtration process that takes place in the sludge blanket in the sedimentation tank. The sludge blanket is a suspension of flocs that is held at the bottom of the settling tank and provides the opportunity for collisions between particles caused by differential settling. Because of the work that the sludge blanket does, AguaClara plants achieve low levels of turbidity in the decanted water even though they use a flocculator with low potential for collisions.

section.names: eficiencia\ del\ floculador flocculator\ efficiency heading_eficiencia\ del\ floculador
section.title: Flocculator efficiency
section.paragraph: The efficiency of potential energy conversion to water deformation depends on the uniformity of the energy dissipation rate. If there are spaces with high turbulence and other spaces with low turbulence the total deformation of the fluid will be much lower than if it had achieved a uniform turbulence given the same energy. Mechanized flocculators and also many conventional hydraulic flocculators make it necessary to consider the impact of non-uniform turbulence space. For example, the rate of energy dissipation is much higher than the average rate behind the tilted propeller blades. Therefore it does not make sense to compare the collision potential calculated by G_{CS}\theta between mechanized flocculators and flocculators that are designed to optimize the uniformity of the energy dissipation rate.

The jet expansion caused by turning around a deflector takes up only part of the space between the following plates (Fig. 24). This expansion is where the turbulence that ultimately causes the deformation of the water and the relative velocities that bring the suspended particles together is found. Within the jet there are regions of high energy dissipation, which indicates violent turbulence and high relative velocities, and there are also areas of softer turbulence. Similarly, there are regions of the flow that contribute very little to flocculation because they are outside the expansion of the jet. If the rate of energy dissipation were uniform it would be an ideal flocculator, with uniform turbulence and the entire volume contributing equally to particle bonding.

figure.caption: Distribution of the rate of energy dissipation in a flocculator according to CFD analysis.

section.paragraph: The geometry of the baffles determines the uniformity of the energy dissipation. In particular, the radius of the jet expansion length to the baffle gap (H/S) is directly related to the expansion uniformity. In other words, this radius determines the efficiency of the flocculator in terms of the percentage of the space that contributes to particle bonding. If the space for expansion is very long compared to the deflector separation, the jet expansion is completed in the first part of the available space and a large part of the flocculator volume is wasted (Fig. 25).

figure.caption: The radius from the length of the expansion to the deflector gap (H/S) determines the spatial uniformity of the energy dissipation.

section.paragraph: According to a series of CFD analyses, the optimal range of the H/S ratio is between |Pi.HSMin| and |Pi.HSTransition|. Here the radius \frac{\varepsilon_{max}}{\bar \varepsilon} is equal to 2. Above the optimal range the turbulence uniformity deteriorates.

Construction restrictions for lower flows require an H/S radius that is too high for efficient design. The minimum height of the channels was determined by the height of the adjacent settling tank, and the minimum width of the channels was determined by the space required during construction. Because of the channel width, the separation between baffles had to be smaller to achieve the required velocity gradient. For simplicity of manufacture, there was only one expansion between every two blades. Especially for smaller flows, the result of these restrictions was an H/S radius well above the optimum range. It was necessary to compensate with a larger flocculator to meet the target collision potential.

The flocculator is now designed with additional obstacles between the sheets that cause additional expansions. In this way the length of the space after each expansion is reduced and the H/S radius can be kept within the optimum range. The obstacles are two pieces of PVC pipe between which the water has to flow, causing a contraction equal to the contraction that occurs after the turn around a baffle.

section.names: la\ tasa\ máxima\ de\ la\ disipación\ de\ energía the\ maximum\ rate\ of\ energy\ dissipation heading_la_tasa_máxima_de_la_disipación_de_energía
section.title: The maximum rate of energy dissipation
section.paragraph: It is not the maximum size of the flocs that really determines the quality of the settled water, but the number of primary particles that have not flocculated by the end of the process. For example, larger flocs, if split in two by the shear force of the flow, will always be captured in the sedimentation tank, since the capture rate is much less than the sedimentation rate of these flocs. The particles that constitute the turbidity of the effluent are much smaller, and it is likely that their origin is due to the lack of coverage of the coagulant, not to the high dissipation of energy.

In several laboratory simulations where the retention time and velocity gradient in a laminar flow flocculator were varied, preliminary data suggest that a reduction in retention time can be compensated for by an increase in the velocity gradient (thus keeping the potential for collisions constant) to produce the same result with respect to settled water quality. It is true that increasing the velocity gradient limits the maximum floc size. Thus, this result suggests that the maximum floc size is not critical to the performance of the treatment system especially when it includes a sludge blanket where flocs continue to grow.

Ultimately, the floccules will be subjected to an energy dissipation rate of |ED.SedInlet| at the inlet to the settling tank to cause |HL.SedDiffuser| of head loss to maintain uniform flow distribution throughout the manifold and to suspend the floccules that have settled to the bottom of the settling tank. Data from the laboratory simulation that was done to test this design suggests that the sediment water quality is not diminished until the rate of energy dissipation at the tank inlet exceeds 300 mW/kg which is equivalent to a velocity gradient of 550 Hz. Since the maximum floc size will be limited by the sedimentation tank inlet, it is clear that it is not necessary to design a flocculator to produce large flocs that will later break up.

Since the velocity gradient at the inlet of the sedimentation tank is higher than the velocity gradient used in the flocculator it is not necessary or convenient to use a series of declining gradients in the flocculator. It is simpler and more efficient to use a single gradient for the entire flocculator to obtain the maximum potential for collisions using the least amount of energy.
